name: 2017_04_humanities_student_major_3288_apstudents
title: 2017-04-humanities-student-major_3288_APStudents.txt
content_scrubbed:
econ itself is great to self-study; depends if you're a macro person tbh. i was more of a micro person bc it dealt with why people behaved the way they did in the economy and had a more "mathematical" edge (not saying there[.] a lot of math, but there[.] more graphs and shit and analysis of tables for opp. cost, game theory, etc. and is focuses on the tiny things in econ) def a better option course if you like psychology, ap enviro science; science in general. to me, i feel like micro is a better self-study.

macro focuses a lot on fiscal/monetary policy, banking, gov't spending, RGDP, unemployment global issues, trading deficits, etc. - if you enjoy the liberal_arts, gov't and politics, and history more, i think this course would be a better fit bc at least in our class we were expected to talk about issues in our economy on a larger scale, unlike micro. it ties in really well with ap us gov/politics. if you hate graphs, this is the course for you; way less graphs than micro but i thought they were more complex to understand because it[.] aggregate demand and supply.

sorry about my micro/macro rant, i'm assuming you're dead set on for macro.
math includes the rule of 70, calculating GDP, tax return rates, etc. very applied math, i would say not ridiculously mathematical at all if you can punch number in your calculator and do basic operations (alg I).
